subsection.title: Trigonometric Functions of Angles in Radians
subsection.p: Measuring angles in radians has other applications besides calculating arclength, and we will need to evaluate trigonometric functions of angles in radians. The sine, cosine, or tangent of a particular angle is the same whether the angle is measured in radians or in degrees.
In Section 4.1 we saw that the sine and cosine are related to points on a unit circle.

assemblage.title: Angles in a Unit Circle
assemblage.p: Let P be a point on a unit circle determined by the terminal side of an angle \theta in standard position. Then the coordinates (x,y) of P are given by \blert{x = \cos (\theta),~~~~~~y = \sin (\theta)}

subsection.p: This fact follows easily from the definitions of sine and cosine, because on a unit circle r=1. In the next Activity we'll use this relationship to get a feel for the trig values of angles in radians.

subsection.title: Using a Calculator
subsection.p: Your calculator can give you the trigonometric function values for angles expressed in radians. For example, \dfrac{\pi}{3} radians is the same as 60\degree, because \dfrac{\pi}{3} \cdot \dfrac{180\degree}{\pi} = 60\degree, so \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) = \sin (60\degree) = \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2} However, we don't have to convert radians to degrees in order to evaluate trig ratios. First, change the calculator setting from Degree mode to Radian mode. Then enter \sin ~(\pi \div 3) and the calculator will return 0.8660254038. You can check that this number is a decimal approximation for \dfrac{\sqrt{3}}{2}.

statement.p: Use your calculator to find the sine and cosine of the following angles in radians. Round your answers to four decimal places.

ol.li: With the calculator in radian mode, and rounding to four decimal places we find \cos (7\pi/4) \amp = 0.7071 \sin (7\pi/4) \amp = -0.7071

Your calculator will also give you the values \cos (3.5) \amp = -0.9365 \sin (3.5) \amp = -0.3508 rounded to four places. Note that 3.5 radians is a third-quadrant angle, so the signs of the trig values make sense.

subsection.p: If two angles are coterminal they have the same trig values, just as they do when measured in degrees. So adding or subtracting a multiple of 2 \pi to any angle results in a new angle in the same standard position and with the same trig values.

statement.p: Find the sine and cosine of the following angles in radians. Round your answers to four decimal places.

li.p: Because \dfrac{5\pi}{2} = 2\pi + \dfrac{\pi}{2},~ \theta is coterminal with \dfrac{\pi}{2},~ and it has the same sine and cosine as \dfrac{\pi}{2}. And \dfrac{\pi}{2} radians is equal to 90\degree, so \sin (\theta) = \sin \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) = 1 \cos (\theta) = \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{2}\right) = 0

Rounded to four places, your calculator will give you the values \cos (-4) \amp = -0.6536 \sin (-4) \amp = 0.7568 By adding 6.2832 (that's approximately 2\pi) to -4 we see that -4 radians is coterminal with 2.2832 radians, a second-quadrant angle. You can check that 2.2832 radians has (approximately) the same trig values as -4 radians.

subsection.p: Recall the formula for arclength when the angle is measured in radians: s = r \theta. If we solve for \theta, we see that \theta = \dfrac{s}{r}, a ratio of two lengths. The units of length cancel out, so that radian measure has no units; it is a "dimensionless" quantity. In other words, a radian measure is just a real number.
We shall see that this property makes radians especially useful in applications. From now on we shall omit the tag "radians," and you may assume that any angle given without units is in radians.

subsection.title: Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers
subsection.p: We have observed that the measure of an angle in radians is just a real number. This is an important observation, because it allows us to define the sine and cosine as functions of real numbers, instead of as functions of angles.

assemblage.title: Sine and Cosine of Real Numbers

subsection.p: We can think of the definition this way: to find the sine or cosine of a real number t, we find the sine or cosine of the angle \theta = t in radians.

note.p: To understand the connection between real numbers and radians, you may find it helpful to remember that the measure of a positive angle in radians is equal to the length of the arc it spans on a unit circle.

sidebyside.p: Consider the unit circle shown at right, and the angle \theta determined by the arc of length t. The radian measure of \theta is the same as the length t of the arc. (For example, in this figure \theta = t = 2.)

note.p: In practice, there is no difference between finding the sine or cosine of the number 2 and the sine or cosine of an angle of 2 radians: in each case we set the calculator in Radian mode and evaluate

subsection.p: So, in some sense then, a trig function of a radian is the same as a trig function of a real number. This result is so important that it bears repeating: to find the sine or cosine of a real number t, we find the sine or cosine of the angle t radians. We can now use the trigonometric functions to model periodic behavior as functions of time, or indeed, of any variable.

statement.p: The sunset time in Stockholm, Sweden, on the nth day of the year can be modeled by T = 3.11 ~\sin ~(0.017n - 1.38) + 6.03 where T is given in hours after noon. Find the sunset time on January 1 (day n = 1) and on July 1 (day n = 182).

image.description: Sinusoidal graph of Stockholm's sunset time vs days

solution.p: Evaluate the function for n = \alert{1} to find T = 3.11 ~\sin ~(0.017(\alert{1}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 2.99 On January 1, sunset in Stockholm occurs about 2.99 hours after noon, or at 2:59 pm.

Evaluate the function at n = \alert{182} to find T = 3.11 ~\sin ~(0.017(\alert{182}) - 1.38) + 6.03 = 9.11 On July 1, sunset occurs about 9.11 hours after noon, or at 9:07 pm. (Actually, 10:07 pm, because of daylight savings time.)

subsection.p: You can set your calculator in radian mode to verify that, to three decimal places, \tan (2) = -2.185

subsection.title: The Special Values
subsection.p: In Chapter 2 you learned the exact trig values for the "special angles" 30 \degree,~ 45 \degree and 60 \degree. Recall that the trig values for these angles can be used as benchmarks for estimating and mental calculation. Now we review those values when the angles are measured in radians.
The easiest way to remember the special values is to refer to the sides of the two special triangles:
You can use these values to find trig values for the special angles in all four quadrants.

Recall that we use reference angles to define the trigonometric ratios for angles greater than 90\degree. (See Section 4.1 to review reference angles.) The figure below shows how to calculate reference angles in radians. Note that the formulas are the same as those for degrees if we replace 180\degree by \pi!

statement.p: Give exact values for the following.

sidebyside.p: The reference angle for \dfrac{2\pi}{3} is \pi - \dfrac{2\pi}{3} = \dfrac{\pi}{3}, and the tangent is negative in the second quadrant. (See the figure at right.) Thus, \tan \left(\dfrac{2\pi}{3}\right) = -\tan \left(\dfrac{\pi}{3}\right) = -\sqrt{3}

The reference angle for \dfrac{5\pi}{4} is \dfrac{5\pi}{4} - \pi = \dfrac{\pi}{4}, and the cosine is negative in the third quadrant, so \cos \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\right) = - \cos \left(\dfrac{\pi}{4}\right) = \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}

note.p: At this point, you may feel that expressions such as ~\cos \left(\dfrac{5\pi}{4}\right) = \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}}~ look like hieroglyphics. Keep in mind that \dfrac{5\pi}{4} and \dfrac{-1}{\sqrt{2}} are just numbers, so the equation above says that "the cosine of an angle of 3.9 radians is about -0.7."
